DataElement.preferredDefinition: the status of a breast cancer margin.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information relating to breast cancer surgery margin.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit.  Breast carcinoma may affect both females and males.  It is the most common malignant tumor and the leading cause of carcinoma death in women.  Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation.  The widespread use of mammography has contributed in the detection of very early cancerous lesions (less than 2mm in diameter).  The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular).  Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route.  The most common site of lymph node involvment is the axilla.  Breast carcinomas infrequently occur in males (particularly elderly individuals and patients with Klinefelter's syndrome).  The therapy of breat carcinoma includes surgery, radiation therapy, hormonal therapy and chemotherapy, depending on the type and extend of the disease. --2002:Used for operative procedures on organs, regions, or tissues in the treatment of diseases, including tissue section by lasers. It excludes transplantation, for which "transplantation" is used.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit. It is the most common malignant tumor in females. Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation. The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular). Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route. The most common site of lymph node involvement is the axilla.

A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.

Property.preferredDefinition: Margin; the boundary line or the area immediately inside the boundary.

Concepts.definition: A boundary line or the area immediately inside the boundary.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: any measurements of a patient's surgical margins.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the status of a breast cancer margin.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A finding of normality following an examination or investigation looking for the presence of a microorganism, disease, or condition.

Concepts.definition: A finding of normality following an examination or investigation looking for the presence of a microorganism, disease, or condition.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A surgical margin which is in close proximity to the excised tumor.

Concepts.definition: An indication that a surgical margin is in close proximity to the excised tumor.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Added concept annotation per request by TCGA. mc 11/12/12

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The presence of microscopically visible residual tumor at the edge of a surgically excised specimen that otherwise looks macroscopically normal.

Concepts.longName: Grossly Negative and Microscopically Positive Surgical Margin
Concepts.definition: The presence of microscopically visible residual tumor at the edge of a surgically excised specimen that otherwise looks macroscopically normal.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The absence of tumor cells at the edge of a surgically excised specimen, both macroscopically and microscopically.

Concepts.longName: Grossly Negative and Microscopically Negative Surgical Margin
Concepts.definition: The absence of tumor cells at the edge of a surgically excised specimen, both macroscopically and microscopically.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Visible to the naked eye.::1: An observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.

Concepts.definition: A finding of abnormality following an examination or observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  WZhang, 02/23/2015

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: In terms of cancer, limited to a specific area.::1: An observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.::2: The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.::3: One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.

Concepts.definition: A finding of abnormality following an examination or observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  WZhang, 02/23/2015
